text: Oh, gosh. I think, given how fascinating I find finance, I think the luckiest break was even getting my first job there, because I left university probably a little bit arrogantly, having a math degree, thinking, oh, I know this stuff. It can't be that hard. It's all math in the end. I'm knowing absolutely nothing about the financial industry, including the difference between the sell side and buy side. And I mentioned before, the first firm I worked for, which was a scientific, I would say, boutique focusing on FX, they took this relatively nerdy, freshly minted mathematician, and they put me through some interviews, and they were kind enough to offer me a job on the first day. So I think that was my break, because I learned a lot from that experience, both in terms of how to think about basic entry to finance, but also when models break down, when markets jump in massive ways in terms of fat tails, et cetera. So I think that was my break, because I learned a lot from that experience, both in terms of how I think about basic entry to finance, but also when models break down, when markets jump in massive ways in terms of fat tails, et cetera. So I think that was my break, because I learned a lot from models break down, when markets jump in massive ways in terms of fat tails, et cetera. So I think that's probably the one I would cite.
